content.value: Viewing and Reading Files in Linux
Viewing files means displaying file content in the terminal without changing or editing it.
content.example: Example: cat notes.txt shows the complete content of the file.

content.value: In Linux, we often read files through the terminal, especially configuration files, logs, and system messages. This helps in understanding errors, checking system status, and reviewing data quickly.
content.example: Think of these commands like 'Windows Notepad', but inside the terminal.

items: cat -> Shows the entire file at once
less -> Scroll and search inside large files
head/tail -> Read specific parts of the file

content.value: Use less for large files; cat is best for short files.
These commands help you view full files, scroll through them, and even monitor live updates.

steps: Use cat filename.txt to view the full file (good for small files).
Use less filename.txt to scroll through page by page. Press Q to exit.
Use tail -f logfile.log to watch logs update live in real time.

content.description: Scroll with ↑ ↓ or SPACE. Quit with Q. Best for large files like logs.

value: Shows the entire file at once. Best for small files where you just want to quickly read everything.
Opens the file in a scrollable viewer. Ideal for large files because you can move up/down, search, and exit with Q.
Shows the first 10 lines of a file. Useful when you only need to check the beginning, such as file headers or configs.
Shows the last 10 lines. Helpful for checking the end of logs, recent changes, or message results.
Live view mode. Continuously updates as the file changes—perfect for monitoring logs and watching errors/events happen in real time.
